questions.text: Match the following? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. i. = c, ii. = a, iii. = d, iv. = b

 

i) Heroine = c) Brown sugar

 

ii) Joint = a) Ganja

 

iii) LSD = d) Acid

 

iv) Eve = b) Amphetamine

 

Explanation:

 

  • i. Heroin = c. Brown sugar
    • Heroin is a semi-synthetic opioid also known by street names such as brown sugar, smack, dope, junk.
  • ii. Joint = a. Ganja
    • A joint is a term used for a rolled marijuana cigarette. Ganja is also known as pot, grass, weed, rope, mull, dope, joint, Mary Jane, skunk, hash, reefer.
  • iii. LSD = d. Acid
    • LSD is known by various street names including acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, purple owle.
  • iv. Eve = b. Amphetamine
    • Methamphetamine and related substances are often referred to as Eve, meth, etc.

 

Educational Objective

 

Street names of narcotic substances

 

  • Ganja is called Pot, grass, weed, rope, mull, dope, joint, Mary Jane, skunk, hash, reefer.
  • Heroin is a semisynthetic opioid also known as brown sugar, smack, dope, junk
  •   Cocaine is called by names like snuff, Rock, Crack, Coke, Snow, Cadillac, White lady
  • Methamphetamine is also called eve, meth etc.
  • LSD is called by names like acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, purple Owle.
  • Abrus Precatorius is called by names like Indian liquor ice, prayer head, crab's eye, weather plant, gulagunchi, ratti, gunja.
  • Capsaicin is called by names like 'Hunan hand' as it causes burning of fingers.

questions.text: A child presents to the clinic with poor wound healing, recurring infections, and delayed bone growth. Physical examination reveals keratosis pilaris and follicular hyperkeratosis. Which of the following can be given to treat her condition? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Correct Answer. The clinical presentation suggests vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A plays a crucial role in immune function, epithelial tissue maintenance, bone growth, and wound healing. The symptoms of keratosis pilaris, delayed bone growth, and recurring infections are classic manifestations of vitamin A deficiency, known as xerophthalmia.

 

Key clinical features of Vitamin A deficiency include:

 

  • Impaired wound healing: Due to reduced epithelial cell regeneration
  • Recurring infections: Compromised immune system function
  • Delayed bone growth: Vitamin A's role in osteoblast and osteoclast activity
  • Skin manifestations: Keratosis pilaris, follicular hyperkeratosis
  • Night blindness: Early sign of vitamin A deficiency

 

The treatment involves vitamin A supplementation to restore immune function, epithelial tissue integrity, and support proper growth and development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Deficiency typically presents with rickets, bone deformities, and calcium metabolism issues. While important for bone health, it does not fully explain the comprehensive symptoms described in this case.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency is rare and usually manifests with neurological symptoms, hemolytic anemia, and muscle weakness. It does not account for the specific clinical picture presented.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Primarily involved in blood clotting and bone metabolism. The symptoms described go beyond the typical manifestations of vitamin K deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency presents with complex systemic implications, affecting immune function, epithelial tissue maintenance, bone growth, and wound healing processes.

 

Key Metabolic Insights:

 

  • Vitamin A is critical for cellular differentiation and immune function
  • Deficiency impacts multiple physiological systems
  • Supplementation can reverse many of the clinical manifestations
  • Plays a crucial role in maintaining epithelial tissue integrity

 

Ref: Advanced Pediatric Nutrition and Metabolism Textbooks

questions.text: By which mechanism does gene repair occur when mediated by CRISPR-Cas9?(AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-Homologous End joining

 

Common repair mechanism in mammalian cells.

 

  • Error-prone: It can introduce insertions or deletions (indels) at the cut site.
  • This mechanism is frequently used in CRISPR-Cas9 to disrupt gene function (gene knock-out).

 

Many clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)-CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9)-based genome editing technologies take advantage of Cas nucleases to induce DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) at desired locations within a genome. Further processing of the DSBs by the cellular DSB repair machinery is then necessary to introduce desired mutations, sequence insertions, or gene deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision: This repair mechanism corrects single-base lesions that do not significantly distort the DNA helix, typically involving the removal of damaged bases by glycosylases followed by endonuclease action.

 

Option C. Homologous End Joining: This term is not commonly used in the context of DSB repair. The correct term would be Homologous Recombination (HR), which is an accurate repair mechanism but not the predominant one in CRISPR-Cas9-mediated repairs.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair: This mechanism corrects base-pair mismatches and small insertion/deletion loops formed during DNA replication and recombination, but it is not primarily involved in repairing DSBs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 mediated gene repair primarily occurs through Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ), an error-prone repair process that ligates broken DNA ends together, often resulting in small insertions or deletions at the repair site.

choices.text: Tandem mass spectrometry
Complete blood count (CBC)

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is preferred for metabolic disease screening in children? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred diagnostic tool for screening metabolic diseases, particularly inborn errors of metabolism (IEM), in children. This technology allows for the simultaneous detection of multiple metabolic disorders by measuring the levels of various metabolites in a single blood sample.

 

The high sensitivity and specificity of tandem mass spectrometry make it an ideal choice for newborn screening programs. It can detect a wide range of metabolic disorders early, enabling prompt intervention that can prevent severe complications and improve long-term outcomes. The method works by ionizing chemical compounds and then analyzing the ions based on their mass-to-charge ratio, which allows for precise identification and quantification of different substances in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete blood count (CBC): CBC is a basic test that measures different components of the blood, such as red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. While it provides essential information about overall health and can help diagnose various conditions, it is not specific or sensitive enough for screening metabolic diseases.

 

Option C. Urinalysis: Urinalysis is a common test that examines the content of urine. It can help detect some metabolic disorders but is not as comprehensive or effective as tandem mass spectrometry for screening a wide range of metabolic diseases.

 

Option D. Genetic testing: Genetic testing is used to identify specific genetic mutations that may cause metabolic disorders. While it can confirm a diagnosis, it is not typically used as the primary screening tool due to its complexity and the time required for analysis. Genetic testing is more often used after an initial screening suggests the presence of a metabolic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard for screening inborn errors of metabolism in children due to its ability to detect multiple metabolic disorders from a single blood sample.

choices.text: 1 and 4 only

questions.text:
A skull was recovered from a forest. According to inquest papers, woman had gone missing after a fight with her boyfriend a month back. The skull was sent to the forensic research lab. Which of the following would identify it as a female skull? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. Large frontal and parietal eminence
  2. Heavy cheek bones
  3. Smooth glabella
  4. Square orbits
  5. Narrow mastoid
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 3 and 5   

 

Female Skull Characteristics:

 

1. Large frontal and parietal eminence: These are more prominent in females.

 

3. Smooth glabella: Females typically have a smoother glabella compared to males.

 

5. Narrow mastoid: Female mastoid processes are generally narrower and less prominent.

 

These characteristics help in identifying the skull as female.

 

Note - General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are

 

  • Size: Male bones are larger than female bones.
  • Roughness: Male bones are more rougher due to increased muscle attachment areas. Females have smooth features
  • Weight: Male bones are heavier than female bones
  • Articular Surface Size: Male bones may have larger articular surfaces compared to females.
  • Square features: Male have square features, whereas females have rounded features

 

So for individual bones, just remember the specific features, instead of general features

 

Other Options

 

2. Heavy cheek bones: Typical in males, as a general rule, female bones are lighter than male bones.

 

4. Square orbits: Males have squarish features, whereas females have roundish features.

 

Educational objective

 

Most features are larger, rougher, and more prominent in male skull, except frontal eminence, parietal eminence and orbits which are more prominent or larger in females

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change. (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Suggillation

 

The image shows post mortem staining on the back, also called suggillation. Post-mortem staining (PMS) is the settling of the blood in the dependent portions of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tattooing: Tattoos appear as distinct, well-defined patterns or designs, often in various colors. Tattoos can be located anywhere on the body and are not necessarily confined to dependent areas. They are typically intentional markings made by injecting ink into the skin.

 

Option C. Putrefaction: The body becomes greenish in colour in putrefaction. Later it becomes blackish.

 

Option D. Decomposition: Same explanation as that of putrefaction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Mortem Staining (PMS)

 

  •  It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.
  • Other names of PMS are:
    • Hypostasis
    • livor mortis
    • Vibices
    • Suggillation
    • Postmortem Lividity
    • Cadaveric lividity
    • Darkening of death
  •  It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.

questions.text: A patient was admitted with complaints of tachycardia, arrhythmias. On examination, multiple scratch marks were present over the body. Probable drug of abuse in above patient is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a powerful sympathomimetic drug that stimulates the central nervous system, leading to symptoms such as tachycardia (rapid heart rate) and arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats). One of the distinctive signs of cocaine abuse is the presence of multiple scratch marks on the body. This occurs due to tactile hallucinations, commonly referred to as "cocaine bugs" or "formication/ Magnan Symptoms" where the user feels as though insects are crawling on or under their skin, causing them to scratch incessantly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morphine: Morphine is a central nervous system depressant, not a stimulant. It typically causes bradycardia (slow heart rate) rather than tachycardia or arrhythmias. It also does not produce tactile hallucinations or scratch marks.

 

Option C. Datura: Although Datura can cause tachycardia and arrhythmias due to its anticholinergic properties, it is not commonly known as a drug of abuse. Moreover, Datura does not typically cause the tactile hallucinations that result in scratch marks.

 

Option D. Cannabis: Cannabis has minimal physiological effects compared to cocaine. It is unlikely to cause significant tachycardia or arrhythmias. Cannabis also does not cause tactile hallucinations or the resultant scratch marks seen with cocaine use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine abuse can be identified by symptoms of tachycardia, arrhythmias, and the presence of scratch marks due to tactile hallucinations (cocaine bugs).

 

“Cocaine is the drug of abuse”

questions.text: Identify the seeds shown in the image below: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nigella sativa 

 

The seeds shown in the given image are of the plant Nigella sativa. 

 

Other names - black cumin or kalonji.

 

Method of action - Sativa modulates the neuronal release of GABA, glycine, aspartate and glutamate on cultured cortical neurons and also possesses a potent central nervous system (CNS) sedative and analgesic activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tropicana canna: This option is incorrect as Tropicana canna refers to a type of plant known for its large, colorful leaves and flowers, not for its seeds.

 

 

Option C. Datura seeds: Incorrect, as Datura seeds are typically flatter and have a distinct shape compared to Nigella sativa. Datura is also known for its toxic properties and is used in traditional medicine with caution.

 

 

Option D. Opium seeds: Incorrect. Opium seeds likely refer to poppy seeds, which are smaller and have a different texture and appearance compared to Nigella sativa seeds.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nigella sativa, or black cumin, is not only recognized for its unique seed appearance but also for its significant medicinal properties, including sedative and analgesic effects on the central nervous system.

questions.text: A lactating mother presents with severe fatigue, brittle nails, and restless legs syndrome. Her blood work reveals increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC) and decreased serum ferritin. Her diet history reveals excessive tea consumption with meals. Which deficiency best explains these symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency

 

Explanation: 

 

Iron deficiency is the correct answer. The presentation shows classic features:

  • Increased TIBC (compensatory mechanism)
  • Decreased ferritin (depleted iron stores)
  • Symptoms of iron deficiency: 
    • Fatigue from anemia
    • Brittle nails (koilonychia)
    • Restless legs syndrome
  • Risk factors: 
    • Lactation (increased iron demands)
    • Tea with meals (tannins inhibit iron absorption)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zinc deficiency: While it can cause growth problems and immune dysfunction, zinc deficiency doesn't affect TIBC or cause anemia-related symptoms.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12 deficiency: B12 deficiency presents with megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms, but TIBC is typically decreased, not increased.

 

Option D. Folate deficiency: Causes megaloblastic anemia but doesn't affect TIBC or cause restless legs syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Students should understand:

 

  1. Iron deficiency diagnostic markers: 
    • Increased TIBC
    • Decreased ferritin
    • Low serum iron
  2. Clinical manifestations: 
    • Fatigue and weakness
    • Koilonychia
    • Restless legs syndrome
    • Pica
  3. Risk factors: 
    • Pregnancy/lactation
    • Dietary factors (tea, calcium)
    • Blood loss
  4. Treatment considerations: 
    • Iron supplementation
    • Dietary modification
    • Addressing underlying cause

questions.text: Patient with high triglycerides esterified with long chain fatty acid (LCFA) presents with fatigue and biopsy of muscle shows fat vacuoles. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carnitine deficiency

 

Carnitine deficiency is a condition in which there is insufficient carnitine to transport long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation, which is the process that generates energy from fats. As a result, LCFAs cannot be oxidized and accumulate in tissues, leading to fatigue, muscle weakness, and the presence of fat vacuoles on muscle biopsy. The accumulation of triglycerides esterified with long-chain fatty acids is characteristic of carnitine deficiency because LCFAs bind to glycerol when they are not oxidized. This condition often presents with symptoms such as exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and, in severe cases, rhabdomyolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FA synthase defect: Fatty acid synthase (FAS) is an enzyme that helps in the synthesis of fatty acids in the body. A defect in FAS usually does not present with the clinical picture seen here since fatty acids can be provided through the diet. It is often benign and does not lead to the accumulation of fat vacuoles in muscles or the described clinical symptoms.

 

Option C. LPL defect: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is an enzyme that breaks down triglycerides in chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) into free fatty acids for tissue uptake. An LPL defect leads to type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by elevated triglycerides, pancreatitis, abdominal pain, and eruptive xanthomas, which do not match the clinical scenario described in the question.

 

Option D. LDL receptor defect: A defect in the LDL receptor results in type 2a hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by elevated LDL cholesterol levels, tendon xanthomas, and a higher risk of atherosclerosis. This condition does not involve the accumulation of fat vacuoles in muscle or present with fatigue related to long-chain fatty acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carnitine is essential for the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation. Deficiency in carnitine leads to the accumulation of triglycerides esterified with long-chain fatty acids in muscle tissues, causing fatigue and exercise intolerance

questions.text: A vegetable vendor with no criminal background, after 1 week is found dead with advanced decomposition. What would you do to recognize the body? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNA profiling

 

After one week liquefaction occurs, so the body undergoes significant decomposition. General recognition is not helpful due to the gross distortion of the body. Dental records are also not useful because teeth typically fall out within three to five days post-mortem. Fingerprints can be compromised as the skin begins to degrade, with degloving of the skin occurring within three to five days and complete skin decomposition taking up to one month. However, DNA profiling remains a reliable method even in advanced decomposition, as DNA can be extracted from bones and other tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. General recognition: This is ineffective after a week of decomposition due to the significant distortion and liquefaction of the body.

 

Option C. Dental records: Teeth fall out within three to five days after death, making dental records unreliable for identification after one week.

 

Option D. Finger prints: The skin undergoes degloving within three to five days and further decomposition, making fingerprinting unreliable. Additionally, without a criminal background, there would be no pre-existing fingerprint records for comparison.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of advanced decomposition, DNA profiling is the most reliable method for identifying a body, as it can still be obtained from bones and other tissues even after significant decomposition.

questions.text: Defect of enzyme tyrosine transaminase(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 2 tyrosinemia

 

Explanation

 

Tyrosinemia is a genetic disorder characterized by the body's inability to effectively break down the amino acid tyrosine. There are three types of tyrosinemia, each associated with a specific enzyme deficiency:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I tyrosinemia: This type is associated with a deficiency in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH), not tyrosine transaminase.

 

Option C. Alkaptonuria: This condition involves a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, not tyrosine transaminase.

 

Option D. Type III tyrosinemia: This type involves a deficiency in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD), not tyrosine transaminase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 2 tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme tyrosine transaminase and is also known as Richner-Hanhart syndrome or Oculocutaneous syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for sample collection in a tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride + Potassium dichromate

 

Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) can be measured through various methods, including gas chromatography. For accurate measurement of BAC, the blood sample is typically collected in a gray-top vial. This vial contains a mixture of sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate.

 

Sodium fluoride acts as a preservative and prevents glycolysis, which could otherwise lower the concentration of alcohol in the blood sample.

 

However, when using the potassium dichromate test for BAC, potassium dichromate is included in the sample collection tube. In this test, potassium dichromate, which is orange in color, reacts with ethanol present in the blood sample. This reaction converts ethanol to acetic acid and simultaneously reduces potassium dichromate to chromium, which turns the solution green. The intensity of the green color directly correlates with the alcohol concentration in the sample, providing a visual indication of BAC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin + EDTA: This combination is generally used as an anticoagulant in blood samples for various laboratory tests but is not specifically used for BAC measurement.

 

Option C. Heparin: While heparin is an anticoagulant, it is not used in the collection tubes for blood alcohol concentration testing.

 

Option D. Sodium citrate: Sodium citrate is also an anticoagulant, commonly used in coagulation studies, but it is not relevant for BAC measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride and potassium dichromate are the substances used in the tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement. Potassium dichromate reacts with ethanol in the blood sample, facilitating the detection and quantification of alcohol concentration

questions.text: Which enzyme serves as the rate-limiting step in bile acid synthesis from cholesterol, and is inhibited by excess bile acids through negative feedback? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7-alpha hydroxylase

 

Explanation: 

 

7-alpha hydroxylase is the correct answer. It is the rate-limiting enzyme in bile acid synthesis because:

 

  • Catalyzes the first committed step in bile acid synthesis
  • Subject to feedback inhibition by bile acids
  • Regulated by cholesterol levels
  • Expression controlled by nuclear receptors

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HMG CoA reductase: While this is the rate-limiting enzyme for cholesterol synthesis, it doesn't directly control bile acid synthesis. It's regulated by cholesterol levels and statins.

 

Option C. Carnitine acyltransferase I: This enzyme controls fatty acid entry into mitochondria for β-oxidation. It's not involved in bile acid synthesis.

 

Option D. Carnitine acyltransferase II: Located in the inner mitochondrial membrane, this enzyme is involved in fatty acid metabolism but not bile acid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Students should understand rate-limiting enzymes in different pathways:

 

  1. Bile acid synthesis: 
    • 7-alpha hydroxylase (CYP7A1)
    • Regulated by bile acids and nuclear receptors
    • First committed step
  2. Key regulatory features: 
    • Feedback inhibition
    • Transcriptional control
    • Response to cholesterol levels
  3. Clinical relevance: 
    • Bile acid metabolism disorders
    • Cholestatic liver disease
    • Gallstone formation

choices.text: Suicidal firearm wounds
Traumatic asphyxia
Drowning
Electrocution

questions.text: Cadaveric spasm is seen in all except: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Traumatic asphyxia

 

Option B. Traumatic Asphyxia : This condition typically results from a severe crush injury to the chest or abdomen that prevents normal respiration. Cadaveric spasms are less likely because the death does not involve a sudden catastrophic nervous system event that would induce immediate muscle contraction.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Suicidal Firearm Wounds : Cadaveric spasm may occur in cases of suicidal firearm wounds due to the intense muscle contraction at the moment of death. The individual might be holding a weapon tightly, which can lead to a cadaveric spasm preserving the grip on the firearm.

 

Option C. Drowning : Cadaveric spasm can occur during drowning as the individual may be holding onto objects or vegetation in a panic, and these grips can become fixed due to the sudden cessation of brain function.

 

Option D. Electrocution : Electrocution can cause instantaneous and intense muscular contractions and possibly a cadaveric spasm. This can result in the deceased gripping onto any objects they were touching at the time of electrocution.

 

Educational objective :

 

Cadaveric spasm is a rare phenomenon usually associated with the sudden and intense activation of muscles at the time of death. It is most commonly seen in deaths involving intense emotional or physical stress where the muscle contraction occurs at or near the moment of death, such as in shootings, electrocution, or drowning.

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription has the base sequence 5'GATCTAC3'. What is the base sequence of RNA product? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5'GUAGAUC3'

 

Explanation:

 

You're given the template strand of DNA:


5′–GATCTAC–3′

 

But remember:

 

  • Transcription reads the DNA template in the 3′ → 5′ direction
  • So we must first reverse the strand to get its 3′ → 5′ orientation
    3′–CATAGTC–5′

 

Now, perform complementary base pairing to make the RNA strand (synthesized 5′ to 3′):

 

 

So the RNA product is:


5′–GUAGAUC–3′

 

Educational Objective

 

The complementary base pairing rules are:

 

  • Adenine (A) pairs with Uracil (U) in RNA.
  • Thymine (T) pairs with Adenine (A).
  • Cytosine (C) pairs with Guanine (G).
  • Guanine (G) pairs with Cytosine (C).

 

The RNA product formed during transcription is complementary to the DNA template strand and follows the base-pairing rules with uracil replacing thymine.

choices.text: Chloride secretion is decreased in sweat and increased in pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is decreased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is increased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid

questions.text: True regarding CF (Cystic Fibrosis): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid:

 

Explanation:

 

In sweat glands, the defective CFTR leads to decreased chloride reabsorption, resulting in increased chloride secretion in sweat. Therefore, individuals with CF have elevated levels of chloride in their sweat, which is a diagnostic feature of the condition.

 

In the pancreas, the impaired CFTR function leads to decreased chloride secretion into pancreatic fluid. This results in the production of thick, sticky mucus in the pancreatic ducts, leading to pancreatic insufficiency. The pancreas is unable to release digestive enzymes properly into the small intestine, affecting the digestion of food.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene. CFTR is a chloride channel that regulates the movement of chloride ions across cell membranes. In individuals with cystic fibrosis, the function of CFTR is impaired.

choices.text: 2 doctors
1 doctor
Medical board
Cannot be done

questions.text: According to MTP Act, MTP at 22 weeks of gestation due to contraceptive failure requires opinion from:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cannot be done

 

Explanation:

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act in India, MTP at 22 weeks of gestation due to contraceptive failure cannot be legally performed. The MTP Act allows termination of pregnancy due to contraceptive failure only up to 20 weeks of gestation.

 

For pregnancies between 20 and 24 weeks, MTP is permitted only in certain aggravated conditions, such as:

 

  • Rape
  • Minors
  • Disabled women
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Widowhood

 

Contraceptive failure is not included in the list of aggravated conditions for which MTP is allowed between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation.

 

Other options:

 

Option. A. 2 doctors: This would be the requirement for MTP between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation in the case of aggravated conditions, but not for contraceptive failure.

 

Option. B. 1 doctor: This is the requirement for MTP up to 20 weeks of gestation, but not for the given scenario of 22 weeks due to contraceptive failure.

 

Option. C. Medical board: A medical board's opinion is required for MTP beyond 24 weeks of gestation, and only in cases of congenital anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: If a woman is undergoing MTP after 24 weeks  of gestation due to congenital anomaly in the fetus , whose presence is not required for authorization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lawyer

 

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) regulations require authorization by a medical board when a pregnancy extends beyond 24 weeks, particularly in cases involving serious congenital anomalies. The board typically comprises a gynecologist, pediatrician, and sonologist—professionals whose expertise is crucial in assessing the risks and conditions related to both the pregnancy and the identified anomaly.

 

A lawyer is not part of this medical board and does not play a role in authorizing MTP, as the decision is purely based on medical assessment rather than legal consultation. The presence of a lawyer is not necessary because the authorization process focuses on the medical justification and safety considerations rather than legal arguments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetrician: The obstetrician is involved in the care of the pregnant woman and is often part of the medical decision-making team, especially when dealing with complex or high-risk pregnancies.

 

Option C. Pediatrician: Pediatricians are essential members of the medical board because they provide expertise on the potential outcomes for the fetus, especially in cases involving congenital anomalies that could impact the fetus's viability or quality of life.

 

Option D. Sonologist: The sonologist's role is crucial as they specialize in ultrasound and imaging, providing detailed assessments of the fetus's condition. Their input is vital in confirming congenital anomalies and guiding the medical board’s decision-making process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MTP after 24 weeks for congenital anomalies, the medical board's authorization is required and comprises a gynecologist, pediatrician, and sonologist. A lawyer’s presence is not required for this authorization process.

questions.text: Female on maize as a staple diet. History of diarrhea and lesion in the neck region. It is due to deficiency of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

This is a typical picture of Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency causing pellagra. Pellagra is characterized by 4Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dermatitis (Casal’s Necklace) dementia and Death can also occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zinc Deficiency is characterized by acrodermatitis (inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers, etc.), diarrhea, alopecia (loss of hair in discrete areas), ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pellagra

 

  1. Maize and Jowar in Diet: The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Jowar has high content of leucine which inhibits tryptophan to Niacin conversion.
  2. Carcinoid syndrome: In this, Trp is mainly used for serotonin formation causes deficiency of trp for Niacin synthesis.
  3. Malabsorption
  4. Drugs like Isoniazid as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.

questions.text: Which toxin can cause acute liver failure and hematuria? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amanita phylloides

 

Explanation:

 

Amanita phylloides, also known as the "death cap" mushroom, contains toxins that can cause both acute liver failure and hematuria. The mushroom contains amatoxins, which are responsible for the severe liver damage, and can also affect the kidneys, leading to renal damage and hematuria. This combination of liver and kidney damage is a characteristic feature of Amanita phylloides poisoning.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option. A. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid that can cause respiratory depression and constipation, but it is not typically associated with acute liver failure and hematuria.

 

Option. B. Ketamine: Ketamine is an anesthetic that can cause dissociative effects and hallucinations, but it is not known to cause acute liver failure and hematuria.

 

Option. C. Belladonna: Atropa Belladonna, also known as deadly nightshade, contains anticholinergic compounds that can cause symptoms such as dry mouth, blurred vision, and tachycardia. However, it is not associated with acute liver failure and hematuria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amanita phylloides, or the "death cap" mushroom, is a toxin that can cause both acute liver failure and hematuria due to the presence of amatoxins. This combination of liver and kidney damage is a characteristic feature of Amanita phylloides poisoning

questions.text: In an isolated mitochondria, in a medium containing Succinate, Fumarate, ADP and Pi, ATPs were produced. Later a compound was added, and oxidative phosphorylation was decreased. What’s that compound? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oligomycin

 

  • Oligomycin is an antibiotic that inhibits ATP synthase, a key enzyme complex in oxidative phosphorylation. It blocks the flow of protons (H+) through ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis. As a result, adding oligomycin would indeed decrease oxidative phosphorylation, leading to a reduction in ATP production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP): 2,4-dinitrophenol is a chemical uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation. It disrupts the proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane, making it leaky to protons. This uncoupling reduces the efficiency of ATP production but doesn't directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option C. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It blocks the transfer of electrons from ubiquinone to cytochrome c, disrupting the electron flow in the chain.

 

Option D. Rotenone: Rotenone is an inhibitor of complex I in the electron transport chain. It prevents the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone, disrupting electron flow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligomycin specifically targets ATP synthase and inhibits ATP synthesis in oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, the compound that was added to the isolated mitochondria, leading to a decrease in oxidative phosphorylation

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 123

questions.text: Ammonia is neutralized and transported from brain tissues through which of the following metabolic pathways? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glutamate dehydrogenase reaction

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glutamate dehydrogenase reaction: Correct Answer. This enzyme plays a critical role in ammonia metabolism by catalyzing the reversible oxidative deamination of glutamate. In brain tissues, the glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) reaction is crucial for ammonia detoxification by directly converting glutamate to α-ketoglutarate while releasing ammonia, which can then be processed by astrocytes through the glutamine synthetase pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alanine transaminase cycle: While alanine transaminase is important in amino acid metabolism, it is not the primary mechanism for ammonia neutralization in brain tissues. This pathway is more associated with muscle-liver ammonia transport and does not directly address brain-specific ammonia management.

 

Option C. Ornithine transcarbamylase pathway: This is a key enzyme in the urea cycle, but it operates primarily in the liver. In brain tissues, the direct neutralization of ammonia occurs through different mechanisms, making this option less relevant to brain-specific ammonia metabolism.

 

Option D. Urea cycle intermediate formation: The urea cycle is predominantly a liver-based process for final ammonia detoxification. Brain tissues employ alternative mechanisms for initial ammonia management, primarily through glutamate dehydrogenase and glutamine synthetase reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ammonia Metabolism in Brain Tissues

 

  • Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) is a key enzyme in brain ammonia metabolism
  • The enzyme catalyzes reversible oxidative deamination of glutamate
  • Brain tissues have specialized mechanisms for initial ammonia neutralization
  • The GDH reaction is part of a complex neurometabolic process for managing nitrogen-containing compounds

 

Key Metabolic Insights:

 

  • Brain ammonia management differs from liver-based urea cycle
  • Glutamate dehydrogenase plays a crucial role in initial ammonia detoxification
  • The reaction involves direct conversion of glutamate to α-ketoglutarate
  • Astrocytes are primary cells responsible for ammonia neutralization in neural tissues

 

Ref: Advanced Neurobiochemistry Texts on Nitrogen Metabolism

questions.text: A newborn presents with seizures and developmental delay. Genetic testing reveals a mutation affecting glucose transport across the blood-brain barrier. Which glucose transporter deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GLUT 1

 

Explanation: 

 

GLUT 1 is the correct answer. GLUT 1 deficiency syndrome occurs due to impaired glucose transport across the blood-brain barrier (BBB) because:

 

  • GLUT 1 is the primary glucose transporter in the BBB
  • Brain cells depend on continuous glucose supply
  • Deficiency leads to cerebral energy crisis
  • Results in seizures, developmental delay, and neurological symptoms

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GLUT 2: While important for glucose sensing in pancreas and liver, GLUT 2 deficiency primarily affects glucose homeostasis and insulin secretion, not brain glucose transport.

 

Option C. GLUT 3: Although present in neurons, GLUT 3 isn't the primary transporter at the BBB. Its deficiency wouldn't cause the initial glucose transport problem across BBB.

 

Option D. GLUT 4: GLUT 4 is insulin-dependent and primarily functions in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissue. It's not involved in brain glucose transport.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Students should understand:

 

  1. GLUT 1's critical role in: 
    • Blood-brain barrier glucose transport
    • Basal glucose uptake
    • Brain energy metabolism
  2. Clinical features of GLUT 1 deficiency: 
    • Early-onset seizures
    • Developmental delay
    • Movement disorders
    • Treatment with ketogenic diet
  3. Tissue-specific functions of GLUTs: 
    • BBB (GLUT 1)
    • Insulin-responsive tissues (GLUT 4)
    • Liver/pancreas (GLUT 2)
    • Neurons (GLUT 3)

choices.text: Right internal jugular vein
Cervical sympathetic chain
Left vagus nerve
Right internal carotid artery

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl committed suicide by hanging, after a fight with her boyfriend. On conducting the autopsy, the ligature mark is seen at the lower 1/3rd of the neck and she is seen to have a protruded tongue. One side eye is open and both the pupils are dilated. What is the cause for the open eye? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervical sympathetic chain

 

In hanging, the ligature knot presses the cervical sympathetic Ganglion, this causes eye on the same side to remain open and pupil dilated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right internal jugular vein: Compression would cause venous congestion but is not directly related to the open eye and dilated pupil.

 

Option C. Left vagus nerve: Compression would affect parasympathetic innervation, potentially leading to bradycardia, but not the open eye and dilated pupil.

 

Option D. Right internal carotid artery: Compression could lead to ischemia, but it does not explain the unilateral open eye and pupil dilation.

 

Educational Objective

 

PM findings of hanging in the Neck

 

  • Petechiae-Tardieu spot
  • La facies sympathique
  • Salivary dribbling
  • Ligature mark
  • Tissues under ligature mark are dry, pale, and glistening
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Hyoid bone fracture

choices.text: If a and c are correct
If a, b and c are correct
a, b, c, & d are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following is correctly matched?

 

  1. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion
  2. Glucose: facilitated diffusion
  3. Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport
  4. Na: Secondary Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, b, c, & d are correct

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion: Oxygen is transported by simple passive diffusion based on the concentration gradient. This process does not require any energy input and relies on the natural movement of oxygen molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.

 

Option B. Glucose: facilitated diffusion: Glucose is transported by facilitated diffusion using glucose transporters (GLUTs) and also through Na-dependent transport using sodium-glucose co-transporters (SGLT). GLUTs facilitate glucose transport without energy, while SGLT uses the sodium gradient to transport glucose into cells.

 

Option C. Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport: Calcium is transported by active transport mechanisms, which require energy. These mechanisms include:

  1. Plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA), which pumps calcium out of the cell.
  2. Sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), which exchanges intracellular calcium for extracellular sodium. Additionally, calcium can be transported via receptor-mediated mechanisms, such as the IP3 receptor, facilitating calcium transport from the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) to the mitochondria.

 

Option D. Na: Secondary Active transport: Sodium often moves down its gradient, but it is also involved in secondary active transport to drive uptake of other substances against their gradients (e.g., glucose in intestines).
The Na⁺/glucose symporter (SGLT) is a classic example.
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each substance (oxygen, glucose, calcium, and sodium) has specific and correct transport mechanisms: oxygen by simple diffusion, glucose by facilitated and Na-dependent transport, calcium by active transport, and sodium by secondary active transport.

 

Reference: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-639

questions.text: A man exposes his genitalia to a female passerby on the road. This method of deriving sexual gratification by observing the people that look at him nude is best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibitionism

 

The given history is suggestive of exhibitionism. Exhibitionism is a condition where an individual derives sexual gratification by exposing their genitalia to unsuspecting people and observing their reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voyeurism

 

  • Definition: Sexual gratification by watching others, typically women, engaged in sexual activity or in a state of undress. The person engaging in this behavior is known as a "peeping tom."
  • Punishment: Punishable under Section 354(C) IPC.

 

Option B. Fetishism

 

  • Definition: Sexual arousal and gratification are achieved through objects or specific body parts, such as footwear, undergarments, etc., often belonging to the opposite sex.

 

Option D. Masochism

 

  • Definition: Sexual gratification is obtained through experiencing pain or humiliation inflicted upon oneself.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Asphyxia
Vagal inhibition
Laryngospasm
Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: An Autopsy was conducted on a male with history of drowning. However, no water was found in his lungs, and he was determined to have experienced ‘dry drowning’. What is the cause of death: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Laryngospasm

 

Option C. Laryngospasm : In cases of dry drowning, laryngospasm is a reflex closure of the vocal cords and other airway muscles that occurs when water touches the vocal cords or throat. This spasm can seal the airway, preventing water from entering the lungs but also air, leading to suffocation.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Asphyxia : In typical drowning cases, this happens when water fills the lungs, preventing oxygen from reaching the blood. However, it isn't the direct cause in dry drowning.

 

Option B. Vagal Inhibition : This refers to a sudden stop of the heart due to a reflex action stimulated by extreme stress or shock, particularly cold water impacting the face. It can instantly stop heart activity but is rare.

 

Option D. Ventricular Fibrillation : Ventricular fibrillation is a severe cardiac rhythm disturbance where the heart's electrical activity becomes so chaotic that the heart stops pumping effectively, leading to sudden cardiac death. It can happen due to severe hypoxia from drowning.

 

Educational objective:

 

Dry drowning is characterized by a laryngospasm that prevents water from entering the lungs but leads to death through asphyxia due to a blocked airway.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homogentisate oxidase

 

Option A. Homogentisate oxidase: This is the correct enzyme.

 

Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase, which leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in the body. This acid can darken upon exposure to air, resulting in blackened urine and other symptoms.

 

It is compatible with fairly normal life. The only abnormality is the blackening of urine on standing. The homogentisic acid is oxidized by polyphenol oxidase to benzoquinone acetate. It is then polymerized to black colored alkaptone bodies.

 

By the 3rd or 4th decade of life, patient may develop ochronosis (deposition of alkaptone bodies in intervertebral discs, cartilages of nose, pinna of ear). Black pigments are deposited over the connective tissues including joint cavities to produce arthritis.

 

Diagnosis of Alkaptonuria:

 

  1. Urine becomes black on standing when it becomes alkaline. Blackening is accelerated on exposure to sunlight and oxygen. The urine when kept in a test tube will start to blacken from the top layer.
  2. Ferric chloride test will be positive for urine.
  3. Benedict’s test is strongly positive. Due to reducing nature of homogentisic acid in urine.

 

Treatment: No specific treatment is required. But minimal protein intake with phenylalanine less than 500 mg/day is recommended.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Xanthine oxidase: Xanthine oxidase is not associated with Alkaptonuria. It is involved in the metabolism of purines, not in the pathway related to this condition.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU), a different metabolic disorder causing mousy/musty body odor.

 

Option D. Dihydro orotate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the pyrimidine biosynthesis pathway and is not related to Alkaptonuria.

 

Educational objective:

 

The diagnosis is alkaptonuria in which urine becomes black on standing due to oxidation of homogentisic acid present in the urine. The disease is autosomal recessive inherited and it is due to the deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase/dioxygenase required for further metabolism of homogentisic acid.

questions.text: In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, which of the following is increased following a fatty meal? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chylomicron

 

Chylomicron levels are increased following a fatty meal in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency. Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is responsible for breaking down triglycerides in chylomicrons. In its absence, chylomicrons accumulate in the bloodstream, leading to elevated chylomicron levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LDL: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) levels may be elevated as well in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, but this increase is primarily associated with genetic factors and not directly related to a fatty meal.

 

Option C. HDL: HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) levels are typically not significantly affected by lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

 

Option D. Apo A: Apolipoprotein A (Apo A) is a component of HDL and is not directly increased following a fatty meal in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frederickson’s classification of hyperlipoproteinemia

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids are necessary for purine ring formation? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine, aspartate, glutamine

 

Explanation

 

Purine ring formation requires the amino acids glycine, aspartate, and glutamine.

 

These three amino acids provide crucial nitrogen and carbon atoms that are incorporated into the purine ring structure during its biosynthesis. Specifically, glycine contributes carbon and nitrogen, aspartate contributes a nitrogen, and glutamine provides another nitrogen atom. This combination is essential for the complex two-ring structure of purines.

 

In contrast, pyrimidine rings, which have a single-ring structure, require only aspartate and glutamine for their formation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Glycine, aspartate, valine: Valine is not involved in purine synthesis. Valine is a branched-chain amino acid used primarily in protein synthesis and energy production.

 

Option C. Glycine, aspartate, glutamate: Glutamate does not participate in purine ring formation. Glutamate is primarily involved in amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis.

 

Option D. D. Glycine, aspartate, alanine: Alanine is not involved in purine ring formation. It is a non-essential amino acid involved in protein synthesis and glucose metabolism, but it does not contribute to the nitrogen or carbon framework of purines.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Important one liner

  • AA for Purines - Aspartate, Glutamine, Glycine
  • AA for Pyrimidines - Aspartate, Glutamine
  • Sources of N & C of Urea - CO2, Ammonia, Aspartate
  • AA linking Kreb's and Urea cycle - Aspartate
  • Molecule linking Kreb's and Urea cycle - Fumarate

choices.text: tRNA of Alanine
U6 SnRNA
mRNA for Histone

questions.text: Which of the following does not require 5' capping? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) tRNA of Alanine

 

5’ capping - Eukaryotic mRNAs are all ‘capped’ at the 5′ terminus by 7-methyl guanosine triphosphate. An unusual 5’ to 5′ triphosphate bridge is seen. This happens inside the nucleus. The cap is useful in recognition of mRNA by the translating machinery and in prevention of degradation by exonucleases.

 

Poly-A Tailing at 3′ End - The 3’ terminus is polyadenylated in the nucleoplasm. This

poly-A tail may be 20 to 250 nucleotides long. This tail protects mRNA from attack by 3′ exonuclease.

 

Note: tRNA do not require capping at 5’ end.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. U6 SnRNA:

  • Function: U6 snRNA is part of the spliceosome complex involved in RNA splicing.
  • Modification: U6 snRNA is not typically capped with 7-methyl guanosine but may undergo other modifications.

 

Option C. mRNA for Histone:

  • Function: Histone mRNAs are unique in that they typically do not have poly-A tails but do require 5' capping.
  • Modification: Despite lacking poly-A tails, histone mRNAs still undergo 5' capping.

 

Option D. SiRNA (Small interfering RNA):

  • Function: SiRNAs are involved in the RNA interference pathway, leading to the degradation of target mRNAs.
  • Modification: SiRNAs are typically not capped at the 5' end as they are processed from longer double-stranded RNA precursors.

 

Educational objective:

 

tRNA, including tRNA for alanine, does not require 5' capping. This modification is specific to mRNAs and some snRNAs, playing a critical role in mRNA stability and translation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with dark urine, which further blackens on exposure to air. What’s the enzyme defect in this case?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Di Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase

 

This is a case of alkaptonuria which is an inborn error in catabolism of tyrosine and phenylalanine. Enzyme deficient is Homogentisate Dioxygenase or Di-Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase. The IUPAC name of homogentisate is 2,5-Dihydroxy Phenyl Acetate. The older name of this enzyme was Homogentisate oxidase. (not Homogentisate Dehydrogenase).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase:

  • Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of tyrosine, an amino acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Tyrosinemia Type I. However, Tyrosinemia Type I does not cause darkening of urine upon exposure to air.

 

Option C. Homogentisate Dehydrogenase

  • Homogentisate oxidase, (not Homogentisate Dehydrogenase) is the enzyme responsible for the metabolism of homogentisic acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Alkaptonuria. In Alkaptonuria, homogentisic acid accumulates and causes the urine to turn black upon exposure to air. This is due to the oxidation of homogentisic acid.
     

 

Option D. Phenylalanine hydroxylase:

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of phenylalanine, another amino acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU does not directly lead to darkening of urine upon exposure to air.

 

Educational objective:

 

In alkaptonuria patients, fresh urine is normal in color, but on standing it turns black due to oxidation of excess homogentisic acid. Homogentisic acid is an intermediate in the catabolism of Tyrosine. For complete list of phenyalanine and tyrosine catabolism defects, refer to topic aromatic amino acids.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 286

questions.text: In a patient with Wilson's disease, which of the following is decreased in urine?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3-methylhistidine

 

3-methylhistidine is decreased in urine in Wilson's disease. This decrease is associated with the abnormal buildup of copper in the liver, leading to decreased excretion of 3-methylhistidine in the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: Tyrosine levels may not be significantly affected in Wilson's disease. The primary concern in this condition is related to copper metabolism rather than amino acids like tyrosine.

 

Option B. Phosphorous: Phosphorus levels are typically not significantly altered in Wilson's disease. The main diagnostic markers for this disorder are related to copper levels.

 

Option C. Serine: Serine levels may not be significantly altered in Wilson's disease. The primary metabolic disturbance in this condition is related to copper accumulation rather than amino acids like serine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson's hepatolenticular degeneration is an inherited autosomal recessive condition.

 

  • The basic defect is a mutation in a gene encoding a copper binding ATPase in cells, which is required for excretion of copper from cells. So, copper is not excreted through bile, and hence copper toxicity.
  • Increased copper content in hepatocyte inhibits the incorporation of copper to apo-ceruloplasmin. So ceruloplasmin level in blood is decreased.
  • Clinical Features
    • Accumulation in liver leads to hepatocellular degeneration and cirrhosis.
    • Deposits in brain basal ganglia leads to lenticular degeneration and neurological symptoms.
    • Copper deposits as green or golden pigmented ring around cornea; this is called Kayser-Fleischer ring.
  • Treatment consists of a diet containing low copper and injection of D-penicillamine, which excretes copper through urine. Since zinc decreases copper absorption, zinc is useful in therapy.
  • Amino acids are excreted in the urine in either conjugated (mostly) or in free form. The amount of conjugated amino acids in urine is far more than free form in Wilson’s disease. Methyl Histidine largely exists in free form and does not increase in amount on hydrolysis of acids in urine, hence the urinary levels of 3-methylhistidine are low in patients with Wilson disease.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Out of the options given below, what is the cause of death in smoke inhalation? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anemic hypoxia

 

Smoke contains multiple substances, of which the most significant component is carbon monoxide (CO). CO can cause both anemic hypoxia as well as histotoxic hypoxia, but predominant cause is anemic hypoxia. Mechanism of hypoxia by CO:

 

  • Anemic Hypoxia by CO: CO combines with hb to form COHb) producing anemic hypoxia (blood O2-carrying capacity is reduced)
  • Histotoxic Hypoxia by CO: While the primary impact of CO is on blood oxygen transport, the presence of COHb can also interfere with cellular respiration at the tissue level. COHb affects mitochondrial function and the electron transport chain, disrupting the cells' ability to utilize the oxygen that is delivered to them.

 

Other options

 

Option A) Histotoxic hypoxia occurs when cells can’t effectively use the available oxygen

due to interference with crucial cellular processes. CO causes histotoxic hypoxia also but the main cause of death is anemic hypoxia. A typical example of histotoxic hypoxia is cyanide poisoning.

 

Option B) Ischemic hypoxia results from inadequate circulation due to conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia in the setting of shock.

 

Option D) All of the above it is incorrect as CO may cause anemic and histotoxic hypoxia but not ischemic hypoxia

 

Educational objective

 

Anemic hypoxia

 

  • Anemic hypoxia is hypoxia  caused by the decreased O2-carrying capacity of blood. It can occur due to two reasons:
    • Hb concentration is low, or
    • Hb concentration may be normal, but it is not able to bind to O2. It can occur due to following conditions:
      • CO Poisoning: It has a higher affinity for Hb than O2 forming COHb.
      • Methemoglobinemia: Methemoglobin is a form of Hb where the iron is in the ferric state (Fe3+) instead of the normal ferrous state (Fe2+). Methemoglobin cannot bind to oxygen effectively.
      • Certain Genetic Hemoglobin Disorders altering the structure of Hb, e.g.

Sickle cell anemia, thalassemia.

choices.text: Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability.
It is a water-soluble vitamin.
Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.
Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about vitamin K? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to Vitamin K deficiency

 

Option C: Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.

 

  • True. Prolonged use of certain antibiotics can disrupt the normal gut flora responsible for synthesizing vitamin K. This disruption can lead to a deficiency in vitamin K, which is essential for blood clotting.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability.

 

  • False. Vitamin K deficiency does not lead to hypercoagulability. Instead, it leads to hypocoagulability, which means impaired blood clotting. Vitamin K is essential for the activation of clotting factors in the blood, and its deficiency can result in bleeding disorders, not excessive blood clotting.

 

Option B. It is a water-soluble vitamin.

 

  • False. Vitamin K is not a water-soluble vitamin; it is a fat-soluble vitamin. Fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamins A, D, E, and K, are absorbed with dietary fats and are stored in the body's fatty tissues.

 

Option D. Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

 

  • Partially true. While menaquinone (vitamin K2) is a form of vitamin K, the primary dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables is phylloquinone (vitamin K1). Both forms of vitamin K are essential for various biological functions.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin.

 

Sources of vitamin K:

 

  • Green leafy vegetables (Phylloquinone/ Vitamin K1)
  • Synthesis by intestinal bacteria (Menaquinones/Vitamin K2)
  • Menadione is synthetic compound metabolized to phylloquinone.

 

In normal adult dietary deficiency seldom occurs since the intestinal bacterial synthesis is sufficient to meet the needs of the body. However, deficiency can occur in conditions of malabsorption of lipids due to obstructive jaundice, chronic pancreatitis, sprue, etc.

 

Prolonged antibiotic therapy and gastrointestinal infections with diarrhea will destroy the bacterial flora and can also lead to vitamin K deficiency.

 

Vitamin K is necessary for coagulation. Factors dependent on vitamin K are Factor II (prothrombin); Factor VII (SPCA); Factor IX (Christmas factor); Factor X (Stuart Power factor) therefore deficiency will to lead to bleeding disorders.

questions.text: The given chemical structure is of: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chondroitin sulphate

 

Chondroitin sulphate is present in ground substance of connective tissues widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea and skin. It is composed of repeating units of glucuronic acid → beta-1,3-N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate → beta-1, 4 and so on.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Keratan Sulphate:

  • Composition: Contains galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine.
  • Location: Found in cartilage, cornea, and intervertebral discs.

 

Option C. Heparin:

  • Composition: Contains glucuronic acid or iduronic acid and glucosamine.
  • Location: Primarily found in mast cells and used as an anticoagulant.

 

Option D. Dermatan Sulphate:

  • Composition: Contains iduronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine.
  • Location: Found in skin, blood vessels, and heart valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chondroitin sulphate is a glycosaminoglycan found in connective tissues like cartilage and bone, characterized by its repeating units of glucuronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate.

questions.text: What does the term "corpus delicti" refer to in legal contexts? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Essence of the offense

 

Explanation:

 

he term "corpus delicti" is a Latin phrase that translates to "body of the crime." It signifies the fundamental facts proving that a crime has been committed. The concept ensures that there must be evidence that a crime has occurred before someone can be convicted for committing the crime. This includes proving that a specific injury or loss resulted from a criminal act.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deceased body: Incorrect. "Corpus delicti" does not mean a dead body. It refers to the essential evidence that a crime has occurred.

 

Option C. Judicial inquiry: Incorrect. A judicial inquiry is a formal investigation conducted by a judge or judicial panel, which is not related to the concept of proving that a crime has taken place.

 

Option D. Police investigation: Incorrect. A police investigation refers to the process of investigating a crime by law enforcement authorities, not to the legal principle of establishing that a crime has occurred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Corpus delicti" refers to the principle that there must be proof of a crime having occurred before someone can be legally convicted of the crime.

questions.text: Decreased transferrin saturation is seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron deficiency anemia

  

Transferrin saturation is a measure of the percentage of transferrin (iron-transporting protein) that is saturated with iron. In iron deficiency anemia, there is a lack of sufficient iron to saturate transferrin, leading to a decreased transferrin saturation. This occurs because the body has insufficient iron for proper incorporation into hemoglobin and other iron-containing proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemochromatosis: In hemochromatosis, there is an excessive absorption and accumulation of iron in the body. This condition leads to increased transferrin saturation, as the body has an excess of iron.

 

Option C. Macrocytic anemia: Macrocytic anemia refers to anemia with larger-than-normal red blood cells. It is commonly associated with deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folic acid. Transferrin saturation is not typically a characteristic feature of macrocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Hemosiderosis: Hemosiderosis refers to the deposition of excess iron in tissues. Like hemochromatosis, it is associated with increased transferrin saturation due to iron overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the concept of transferrin saturation and how it relates to various conditions related to iron metabolism. Decreased transferrin saturation is typically seen in conditions of iron deficiency, such as iron deficiency anemia, where there is insufficient iron to fully saturate transferrin.

choices.text: Glutamine replaced by asparagine
Glutamine replaced by alanine
Glutamine replaced by glutamate
Glutamine replaced by arginine

questions.text: Which of the following would have no effect on the function of the protein product? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glutamine replaced by asparagine

 

Amino acid replacement is a change from one amino acid to a different amino acid in a protein due to point mutation in the corresponding DNA sequence. It is caused by nonsynonymous missense mutation which changes the codon sequence to code other amino acid instead of the original.

 

Usually, amino acids are thus classified into two types:

 

  1. Conservative replacement - an amino acid is exchanged into another that has similar properties. This type of replacement is expected to rarely result in dysfunction in the corresponding protein.

For example, leucine and isoleucine are both aliphatic, branched hydrophobes. Similarly, aspartic acid and glutamic acid are both small, negatively charged residues.

 

  1. Radical replacement - an amino acid is exchanged into another with different properties. This can lead to changes in protein structure or function, which can cause potentially lead to changes in phenotype, sometimes pathogenic.

 

Example - Sickle cell anemia, due to a mutation in beta globin where at position 6 glutamic acid (negatively charged) is exchanged with valine (not charged).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glutamine replaced by alanine: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while alanine is a nonpolar, aliphatic amino acid. This radical replacement could affect the protein's structure or function.

 

Option C. Glutamine replaced by glutamate: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while glutamate is a polar, negatively charged amino acid. Although they are similar in size, the difference in charge makes this a radical replacement, potentially affecting protein function.

 

Option D. Glutamine replaced by arginine: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while arginine is a polar, positively charged amino acid. This radical replacement could significantly alter the protein's structure or function.

 

Educational Objective

 

Conservative replacements, such as replacing glutamine with asparagine, typically do not affect the protein's function because the substituted amino acids have similar properties. Radical replacements, involving amino acids with different properties, are more likely to impact protein function.

questions.text: Identify the pattern of abrasion shown in the image below? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ligature mark

 

A ligature mark is a well-known pressure mark on the neck underneath a ligature. It is a common injury in cases of hanging and strangulation.

 

Ligature Mark:

 

  • Appearance: Typically presents as a horizontal or slightly diagonal mark around the neck.
  • Cause: Caused by the application of a ligature (e.g., rope, cord, or similar object) under tension.
  • Context: Commonly associated with homicidal, suicidal, or accidental hanging and strangulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Graze abrasion: Caused by scraping or sliding friction against a rough surface, resulting in superficial loss of skin.

 

Option C. Brush burns: Result from friction burns, often appearing as red, inflamed, and abraded areas of skin.

 

Option D. Imprint abrasion: Caused by the impact of a patterned object, leaving an imprint on the skin.

 

Educational objective

 

Types of abrasions:

questions.text: A combination of traumatic asphyxia and smothering is called: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burking

 

Burking:

 

  1. It includes homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxiation
  2. Named after Burke and Hare
  3. Burke used to sit on the chest of victim and close his mouth and nostrils by hand and Hare used to pull him round the room by feet.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gagging: Involves placing a gag in the victim’s mouth to prevent them from making noise, not necessarily causing death through asphyxia.

 

Option C. Choking: Refers to the obstruction of the airway by an internal object, preventing breathing.

 

Option D. Traumatic Asphyxia: A condition caused by severe compression of the chest, leading to impaired breathing and oxygen deprivation, but not necessarily combined with smothering.

 

Educational Objective:


Burking involves a deadly combination of traumatic asphyxia and smothering, making it a unique and specific method of homicide.

 

Ref: Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 119.

questions.text:
The drowned dead body of a young man found in the sea and was brought in for postmortem examination. Which of the following findings do you see in seawater drowning? (INICET May 2021)
